items.title: When power isn’t guaranteed: Indigenous families in northern Australia face deadly risks in extreme heat
items.summary: Thousands of Indigenous households across northern Australia live with prepaid power, where disconnection can happen at any moment. Now a new report has warned that without stronger protections, the system could turn deadly in extreme heat. SBS’s Christopher Tan travelled to the Kimberley to see what life is like when power is a privilege, not a guarantee.

items.title: UN-backed hunger monitor confirms famine in Sudan's Al-Fasher and one other city
items.summary: The Integrated Food Security Phase Classification has concluded that the cities recently taken by the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces are in famine.

items.title: Mushroom murderer to appeal convictions | Morning News Bulletin 4 November 2025
items.summary: The death toll rises from an earthquake in northern Afghanistan,Mushroom murderer Erin Patterson lodges an appeal against her convictions, 24 local and international horses to compete in the Melbourne Cup.

items.title: Magnitude-6.3 earthquake kills at least 20 people in Afghanistan
items.summary: The US Geological Survey said the quake hit at a depth of 28km near Mazar-e Sharif, a city of around 523,000 people famous for its shrines and historic sites.

items.title: Why these skincare products with a banned ingredient are still being sold in Australia
items.summary: Six skincare brands have been ordered to withdraw their products from supermarket shelves in NSW after being found to contain banned microbeads.

items.title: Traditional Owners are fighting to bring this famous crocodile home
items.summary: Traditional Owners in Cape York say they were blindsided by the relocation of Old Faithful — a crocodile they consider a family member — to Australia Zoo, nearly 2,000km away.

items.title: Man charged with attempted murder after mass stabbing on UK train
items.summary: A 32-year-old man faces 10 attempted murder charges after a mass stabbing on a London-bound train that left 11 people injured and a crew member fighting for life.

items.title: CEO SERIES: Westpac CEO Anthony Miller on results, rates outlook, restructure and AI
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Westpac CEO Anthony Miller about the bank's full-year results to find out what will drive growth in the future, and takes a look at the market reaction with David Walsh from Sarto Advisory Pty Ltd.

items.title: COP30 summit kicks off in Brazil, as business leaders push for clean energy
items.summary: Brazil's turn as this year's host marks 33 years since the Rio Earth Summit, where countries first signed the United Nations treaty to tackle climate change.

items.title: Traditional owners object to movement of 'Old Faithful' crocodile made famous by Steve Irwin
items.summary: Traditional owners in far north Queensland are calling for an iconic saltwater crocodile to be returned to country. The croc, named 'Old Faithful', featured in the Crocodile Hunter series alongside the late Steve Irwin - but he's been re-homed far from his natural habitat following concerns over aggressive behaviour.

items.title: Who is Zohran Mamdani? The self-described socialist could become New York's next mayor
items.summary: Zohran Mamdani has garnered the support of major Democratic figures, including former US president Barack Obama.

items.title: What the RBA decision means for the 'sense of urgency' in the property market this spring
items.summary: Spring has meant a bump in the number of new listings, which could offer an "opportunity" for first-time buyers.

items.title: Optus CEO berated at Parliamentary Inquiry | Evening News Bulletin 3 November 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, Optus boss is under fire at a senate inquiry into a deadly communications outage, Parliament passes a bill to protect paid leave for grieving new parents. In football, Arsenal increases its lead in the English Premier League ladder after a win against Burnley.

items.title: 'What on earth?': Optus defends fatal outage response at Senate inquiry
items.summary: Under-fire Optus executives have copped a parliamentary bashing for their response to a triple-zero outage linked to the deaths of three people. The proceedings have immediately zeroed in on CEO Stephen Rue, who is being pressured to explain a significant delay in reporting the fatalities to both the government and the regulator.

items.title: Ley downplays net zero rift, with Liberals divided after Nationals dump policy
items.summary: The Nationals’ decision to dump support for net zero has renewed questions about the Coalition's unity, as Sussan Ley downplays internal divisions.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 3 November 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: 'Dignity': Baby Priya bill passes, protecting parental leave for stillbirth and infant deaths
items.summary: The Albanese government said the laws give grieving parents financial certainty after stillbirth or infant death.

items.title: 'Dignity': Baby Priya bill passes, protecting parental leave for stillbirth and infant deaths
items.summary: The Albanese government said the laws give grieving parents financial certainty after stillbirth or infant death.

items.title: INTERVIEW: Eliza Owen from Cotality on the RBA's impact on the property market
items.summary: Spring is historically the time of year that sees the most new listings in the property market - and the highest sales volumes. But with rumours that the RBA is likely to keep interest rates on hold until next year, what effect will that have on sales? Eliza Owen from Cotality (formerly Corelogic) spoke to SBS's Cameron Carr

items.title: Optus boss rejects calls to resign | Midday News Bulletin 3 November 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, Optus CEO rejects calls to quit his role, as he faces Senate Inquiry, the Coalition attempts to reach a consensus on its climate policy. In cricket, India wins its first-ever Women’s World Cup.

items.title: UK Train stabbing attack: One in custody, not terrorism say police
items.summary: After a mass stabbing on a train in the UK left 11 people hospitalised, police say they have no evidence suggesting the attack was related to terrorism.With one suspect now in custody, authorities in the UK are urging the public to give time for a full investigation into the motives behind the incident.

items.title: 'What were you doing?': Optus executives grilled over 17-hour delay during triple-zero outage
items.summary: During a Senate inquiry, Optus executives were asked why they left the government "in the dark" following a triple-zero outage.

items.title: 'What were you doing?': Optus executives grilled over 17-hour delay during triple-zero outage
items.summary: During a Senate inquiry, Optus executives were asked why they left the government "in the dark" following a triple-zero outage.

items.title: Hamas hands over three more hostage bodies as Israel continues deadly strikes
items.summary: Israel and Hamas have accused each other of violating a ceasefire in the Gaza Strip, as the militant group handed over more bodies of hostages.

items.title: Nationals ditch net zero as Liberals ponder their own climate policy
items.summary: The Nationals have formally walked away from support of Australia's net zero emissions by 2050 policy after a party room meeting in Canberra. The decision sets up a potential showdown with their coalition partner the Liberals, who are also reviewing their approach to climate change after their disastrous election defeat.

items.title: UK stabbing attack: four in life-threatening condition | Morning News Bulletin 3 November 2025
items.summary: No evidence UK train stabbings were a terror attack; focus shifts to the Liberals after Nationals abandon net zero; New Zealand facing Samoa in the Pacific Cup final.

items.title: Powerless: The hidden crisis of prepaid energy and First Nations communities
items.summary: In Western Australia's remote north, tens of thousands of people are living in fear of sudden disconnection and being forced to ration power.

items.title: My son begged me not to tell anyone he was being bullied. I didn't listen
items.summary: Nama Winston's son was being bullied over his sexuality. She told his school principal, whose response "blew her away".

items.title: The 'Hotel California effect' and how Australians are spending more on subscriptions
items.summary: Australians are paying more than ever for their subscriptions, but not because they’re watching or listening more.

items.title: What is net zero, and why have the Nationals abandoned it?
items.summary: An environmental expert says the Nationals are "representing the big mining bodies" instead of regional Australians.

items.title: Nine people critical after mass stabbing on UK train
items.summary: [[A WARNING THAT THIS STORY CONTAINS GRAPHIC DESCRIPTIONS]] Ten people have been injured - nine of them critically - after a stabbing rampage on a train in London. The country's Prime Minister has called the attack deeply concerning. Counter terrorism police are now investigating the incident.

items.title: Evening News Bulletin 2 November 2025
items.summary: Counter terrorism police investigating a mass stabbing on a London train; he Nationals officially abandon their support for a net zero emissions policy; Queensland's Matthew Hauser claims the Noosa Triathlon title.

items.title: Infant peanut feeding prevented thousands of children from developing allergies
items.summary: New US research reveals early introduction of peanuts has prevented about 60,000 children from developing dangerous food allergies.

items.title: Victims of IVF provider data breach seek compensation in complaint to national regulator
items.summary: Patients from one of Australia's largest IVF clinics are seeking compensation following a data breach earlier this year.

items.title: Nationals abandon net zero after members vote to dump climate target
items.summary: The Nationals say Australia's commitment to net zero emissions by 2050 is driving up power prices and shutting down industry.

items.title: Midday News Bulletin 2 November 2025
items.summary: Several people stabbed on a UK train, with two men now in custody; The Nationals poised to abandon their net zero stance; England overpower the Wallabies at Twickenham.

items.title: Peter is part of Australia's 'silent epidemic'. A new initiative offers hope
items.summary: One in twenty Australians aged 75 and above is diagnosed with kidney disease but authorities suspect the vast majority of cases go undetected.

items.title: One man in custody after UK train stabbing leaves two with 'life-threatening' injuries
items.summary: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer said the "appalling" incident was "deeply concerning".

items.title: One man in custody after UK train stabbing leaves two with 'life-threatening' injuries
items.summary: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer said the "appalling" incident was "deeply concerning".

items.title: One man in custody after UK train stabbing leaves two with 'life-threatening' injuries
items.summary: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer said the "appalling" incident was "deeply concerning".

items.title: INTERVIEW: Mary Wooldridge, CEO of the Workplace Gender Equality Agency
items.summary: A new report released this week by the Workplace Gender Equality Agency (WGEA) has found the financial cost of the gender pay gap accelerates across a woman’s lifetime, peaking in the late 50s at a difference of $53,000. WGEA’s Ages and Wages report investigates how and why the gender pay gap changes at different stages across a lifetime. It lists key actions employers can take to address it. WGEA CEO Mary Wooldridge spoke to SBS On the Money's Stephanie Youssef

items.title: Man charged with murder after mother-of-three found dead in Hunter Valley home
items.summary: One of the woman's children is understood to have run to a neighbour's property for help after the incident.

items.title: Youth justice: Is jailing failing First Nations kids, inquiry asks
items.summary: State and territory governments in Australia will face scrutiny as part of a parliamentary inquiry on the outcomes and impacts of youth incarceration. The over-incarceration of First Nations children will also be a key focus.

items.title: As battle for 'gateway to Donetsk' intensifies, Ukraine says its troops are still holding out
items.summary: Pokrovsk, in Ukraine's Donetsk region, lies on a major supply route for the Ukrainian army and has been in Moscow's sights for over a year.

items.title: How Australia's north is being used by defence allies for regional security
items.summary: As Australia deepens its engagement in the Indo-Pacific region, strategic partners are more important than ever. Australia's longstanding military alliance with American forces is being expanded into the future. Josh van Staden takes a look inside the US Marines base near Darwin, where thousands of US Marines have recently departed as part of an annual rotational force.

items.title: England introduces new law to make social housing safe after toddler’s death
items.summary: England has a new law that will force social housing landlords to ensure their property is safe. The legislation came about as a result of the death of a two-year old boy who died from breathing in black mould which infested his family's home.

items.title: Morning News Bulletin 2 November 2025
items.summary: Nationals MPs poised to formally abandon support for net-zero; Tanzania's incumbent president claims a landslide win; Kangaroos edge England to retain the Ashes series.

items.title: Early super access let Damian fix his teeth. For Melinda, it was a $48,000 nightmare
items.summary: More Australians are dipping into super for dental care. But for some, it's left them with both financial and physical pain.

items.title: The facial tattoos sending a 'very clear statement' after decades of suppression
items.summary: Tā moko is part of a sacred tradition. For some, it's also a message to the government.

items.title: Snipping and sharing: The young people posting about their vasectomies online
items.summary: With an ageing population, China wants more people to have babies. But some men are posting on social media about their vasectomies instead.

items.title: Evening News Bulletin 1 November 2025
items.summary: The Nationals Federal council dumps net zero from their policy platform; The UN alarmed by deadly post-election violence in Tanzania; Driver Liam Lawson cleared over a near-miss with Formula One Grand Prix officials.

items.title: Nationals members vote to ditch net zero, paving the way for party to dump target
items.summary: The motion passed by Nationals' grassroots members called on the party to "abandon its support for a net-zero mandate" while still reducing emissions.

items.title: Fast fashion giant H&M investigated over multimillion-dollar underpayment claims
items.summary: H&M says it discovered widespread payroll discrepancies dating back to 2016 and has launched a remediation process, including back pay.

items.title: Landmark aged care reform set to protect elderly rights but fears some could be worse off
items.summary: A landmark overhaul of the nation's aged care rules is in effect, enshrining older Australians' rights into law but also pushing up some prices.

items.title: Midday News Bulletin 1 November 2025
items.summary: Government announces the biggest overhaul of aged care in a generation... United Nations urges safe passage for Darfur civilians as fighting intensifies... Jamie-Lee Price crowned Australian netball's top player.

items.title: They're the world's most hidden societies — and they're 'under attack right now'
items.summary: The world's uncontacted Indigenous groups are facing growing threats, according to a human rights organisation.

items.title: 'You'll find out soon': Trump declines to rule out underground nuclear tests
items.summary: No nuclear power — other than North Korea — has carried out explosive nuclear testing in over 25 years.

items.title: 'Populists can be beaten': Dutch centrist Rob Jetten claims knife-edge election win
items.summary: With far-right parties on the march in France, Germany, and Britain, the Dutch vote was widely seen as a bellwether for the strength of populists in Europe.

items.title: 'Populists can be beaten': Dutch centrist Rob Jetten claims knife-edge election win
items.summary: With far-right parties on the march in France, Germany, and Britain, the Dutch vote was widely seen as a bellwether for the strength of populists in Europe.

items.title: Multicultural communities report a greater sense of belonging, new SBS report reveals
items.summary: A new report by SBS and the University of Canberra have found there is an increased sense of belonging among multilingual communities compared to 2023. It also details factors that could affect the levels of civic participation among multilingual communities, and the different attitudes toward sense of belonging between younger and older generations of multilingual Australians.

items.title: Aged care reforms: Who will pay more under the new system?
items.summary: A long-awaited Aged Care Act comes into force today [[Nov 1]], four years after a Royal Commission recommended major reforms to the sector. The federal government says it will give older Australians more choice and access to in-home support, but there are concerns many people will end up paying more for care.

items.title: INTERVIEW: Graeme Samuel tells SBS why he endorses the government's environmental bill
items.summary: The author of the review that triggered the government's environment reforms has fully endorsed Labor's nature legislation. Professor Graeme Samuel has told SBS the bill implements the 'totality' of the recommendations he made in his report, five years after it was delivered. The Greens and Coalition have objected to the bill, with Greens leader Larissa Waters describing it as 1400 pages gift-wrapped for big business. But Professor Samuel says environmental groups and business interests alike had substantial input into his report, and their desires were fully taken into account in the recommendations. He's been talking to SBS chief political correspondent Anna Henderson.

items.title: Tanzania's president declared landslide winner in election marred by violence
items.summary: United Nations chief Antonio Guterres has called for a "thorough and impartial investigation" into recent violence in Tanzania.

items.title: At the edge of survival: report says half of uncontacted Indigenous peoples facing extinction
items.summary: A not for profit organisation says almost half of Indigenous communities living cut off from the world face extinction within the decade due to logging, mining and tourism. Survival International says they want the world - especially governments and industries - to recognise and address the problem as a global emergency.

items.title: Morning News Bulletin 1 November 2025
items.summary: Anthony Albanese wraps up Asia tour as Xi Jinping and Donald Trump dominate APEC summit, A long-awaited Aged Care Act comes into force today Australia beat India by four wickets as Marsh and Hazlewood shine at the MCG.

items.title: 'No idea how much they're having': The party drug on the rise among young women
items.summary: Once thought of as mostly a 'date rape drug', GHB is being used recreationally by more Australians and experts say it's causing problems.

items.title: Sudanese-Australians face terrifying ordeal after ransom demanded for cousins
items.summary: Cut off from loved ones in Sudan, Abdullah Gaka's phone is his only link to a city gripped by siege, starvation and fear.

items.title: Investors consider rate pause and AI investment costs
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Grady Wulff from Bell Direct about the day's market action including how the interest rate outlook is impacting the market and AI profitability.

items.title: 'It’s the beginning': Next move after Victoria's historic Treaty milestone
items.summary: Victoria is the first state or territory in Australia to pass legislation that paves the way for a Treaty with First Peoples.

items.title: The Australians facing a $53k pay problem — and the age it hits hardest
items.summary: A new report has revealed for the first time that the gender age gap starts at 30, and only increases as women get older.

items.title: Disgraced former minister sentenced to five years in jail | Evening News Bulletin 31 October 2025
items.summary: Disgraced former minister sentenced with five years and nine months in prison for sexual abuse; Sudanese Australians concerned for family overseas; and in sport, international Rugby League rules out changes to eligibility rules.

items.title: 'Power grab': Labor under fire over new move to cut off Centrelink payments
items.summary: The last-minute additions have been called into question, with advocates arguing they set a "dangerous precedent".

items.title: INTERVIEW: Jill Gallagher, VACCHO, on the new Victorian treaty
items.summary: Victoria's First Nations community is celebrating a historic milestone - legislation to establish the first treaty in Australia's history passed through state parliament on Thursday night. It's expected to enter force by the end of the year, after an official signing ceremony and royal assent from Victoria's governor, in the culmination of a whole decade of negotiations. The legislation establishes a permanent Aboriginal advisory and decision-making body, to be known as Gellung Warl, which will remain outside the state's constitution. Aunty Jill Gallagher is the C-E-O of the Victorian Community Controlled Health Organisation, and served as the Treaty Advancement Commissioner in 2018. She's been talking to SBS's Tee Mitchell.

items.title: Victoria passes Australia’s first treaty law, creating permanent Indigenous voice in parliament
items.summary: After almost a decade of activism and community efforts, Victoria has passed Australia's first ever treaty legislation establishing a permanent Indigenous representative body in the state parliament. The landmark agreement between the Victorian Government and the First People's Assembly of Victoria marks a historic step towards recognising and reckoning with Victoria's violent colonial history.

items.title: The Halloween ghost craze in England's spookiest city
items.summary: York in northern England is a historic city with a long tradition of spooky sightings and eerie apparitions. This Halloween, the city is celebrating its connections with ghosts.

items.title: Calls for help as Melissa leaves a trail of destruction across the Caribbean
items.summary: Hurricane Melissa has left a trail of devastation across the northern Caribbean, striking Jamaica, Cuba and Haiti before sweeping towards Bermuda. One of the most powerful Atlantic storms on record, it has killed at least 30 people, displaced thousands and crippled vital infrastructure. Recovery efforts are now under way across the region.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 31 October 2025
items.summary: A five minute bulletin for English language learners

items.title: From prince to pariah: A timeline of Andrew's alleged acts and long fall from grace
items.summary: Andrew Windsor has faced criticism for his ties to Jeffrey Epstein for more than a decade.

items.title: Victoria makes history with Australia's first Indigenous treaty | Midday News Bulletin 31 October 2025
items.summary: Victoria's parliament passes a historic treaty with First Nations people, Coalition MPs meet to discuss net zero policy, Australia's women lose their World Champions title as India triumphs after a massive run chase.

items.title: King Charles wants Andrew evicted, but Virginia Giuffre's family wants him 'behind bars'
items.summary: The comments come after Buckingham Palace announced it was stripping Andrew of his 'prince' title.

items.title: Environmental reform architect hails end to 'torturous' years, hits out at Greens and Coalition
items.summary: Graeme Samuel beamed as he praised laws sparked by his landmark review, while saying the Greens and Coalition don't get them.

items.title: 'Swiss cheese' reforms: What's wrong with Australia's nature laws?
items.summary: This sitting week has brought a storm over the BoM's new website, controversy about a t-shirt and some massive proposed reforms to Australia's environmental laws. To help us sort through what on earth is happening with the EPBC (and explain what it is) we spoke with Dr Kirsty Howey from the Environment Centre NT.

items.title: Donald Trump's nuclear testing order sparks pushback from Russia, China and the UN
items.summary: Trump said the Pentagon will immediately resume testing the US nuclear arsenal on an "equal basis" with other nuclear powers.

items.title: Prince Andrew stripped of royal title, forced to leave Windsor mansion
items.summary: King Charles' brother will be known as Andrew Mountbatten Windsor, amid criticism over his ties to sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

items.title: 'Out of order': Senate descends into chaos as Coalition accused of silencing women
items.summary: The chaotic scenes occurred during a marathon three-hour Question Time — the longest since federation nearly 125 years ago.

items.title: Family and friends 'taken or killed': From Australia, Emad is watching horrors unfold
items.summary: As Sudan's Darfur region faces an escalating crisis, hundreds are dead and families abroad wait helplessly for news of loved ones.

items.title: The future of AI investment if interest rates don't fall as much as expected
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with market analyst Evan Lucas about the implications of another US interest rate cut, talk a follow up in December isn't assured and what it means for AI investment; plus the AFR's Yolanda Redrup on the trends making young people rich.

items.title: First Nations businesses forge new connections in India
items.summary: A group of First Nations Australian business owners and operators are in India showcasing their businesses, as part of a push to build ties between Indigenous communities in the two countries. The aim is to expand opportunities for Indigenous participation in international trade, three years after a historic trade agreement was signed between India and Australia.

items.title: Barnaby Joyce denies female staffer abuse allegations ahead of parliamentary investigation
items.summary: A formal complaint against the former deputy prime minister has been lodged with parliamentary support services.

items.title: Government introduces environment laws to Parliament - but hurdles remain
items.summary: Australia's most significant environmental law reform in decades has been tabled in Parliament, but it faces immediate political deadlock with opponents in the Senate ready to delay the vote. As Minister Murray Watt pushes for a swift resolution, he must navigate an environment where both the Coalition and the Greens are demanding major concessions on accountability, climate, and industry protection.

items.title: Trump says Xi meeting 'amazing' as he cuts tariffs and claims rare earths 'settled'
items.summary: Talks between Donald Trump and Xi Jinping follow months of friction over tariffs and security.

items.title: Trump touts Asia triumph - and a third term, Russia's oil sanctions & 'et tu' Queensland?
items.summary: Donald Trump talks up tributes and tariff deals on his Asia tour, as well as the possibility of a third term as he stops in on the ASEAN and APEC summits. In Gaza, Israel and Hamas accuse each other of ceasefire violations. US sanctions on Russian oil piles the pressure on Putin, and a curriculum catastrophe for Queensland students.

items.title: Rio de Janeiro governor defends raid that favela residents say was a "massacre"
items.summary: A week out from hosting thousands of international visitors for the United Nation's climate summit, Brazilian authorities are clearing the aftermath of what has become one of the deadliest police raids in the nation's history. The president says he had no warning of the scale of Rio de Janiero's police raid and the U-N is calling for an independent investigation.

items.title: $136,000 superannuation warning as Australia faces a 'silver tsunami'
items.summary: Millions are heading into retirement over the next decade — and some could be left thousands of dollars behind, a new report says.

items.summary: A five minute bulletin for English language learners

items.title: 'Unimaginable tragedy': Inquiry launched into suicide related to domestic and sexual violence
items.summary: Social Services Minister Tanya Plibersek said the inquiry was vital to understand the full picture of domestic violence.

items.title: Dozens dead, thousands homeless after Hurricane Melissa batters Caribbean
items.summary: Hurricane Melissa has carved a path of devastation through the Caribbean this week, first battering Jamaica, then surging into Cuba. It's left tens of thousands homeless, power grids faltering, and nations mobilising aid. At least 27 people are confirmed dead across Jamaica, Haiti, and Cuba, with early estimates suggesting hundreds of millions of dollars in damage.

items.title: 'Rosaries off our ovaries': Coalition MPs face growing criticism over abortion claims
items.summary: Suggestion that ensuring maternity leave for women who experience stillbirths could have "unintended consequences" has raised eyebrows.

items.title: Rights groups condemn 'horrific' Sudan hospital killings as thousands flee Al-Fasher
items.summary: The World Health Organization said more than 460 people had been killed at a maternity hospital in Al-Fasher.

items.title: More than 100 Palestinians killed in Israeli airstrikes on Gaza, health ministry says
items.summary: Israel's strikes mark the worst escalation of violence in Gaza since a ceasefire came into effect earlier this month.

items.title: How much does it really cost to raise a child in Australia? Here are the numbers
items.summary: Calculating the cost of raising kids is a complicated beast.

items.title: 'Significant breaches': Is Trump's campaign against alleged 'drug boats' illegal?
items.summary: The Pentagon has provided few details on the quantity of drugs the boats allegedly carried and the identities of those killed.

items.title: Labor faces a Christmas crossroads over its environment laws reboot
items.summary: Environment Minister Murray Watt has challenged both the Coalition and Greens to come to the table to deliver major environmental reform.

items.title: INTERVIEW: Satellite evidence reveals 'Rwanda-level' massacres in Sudan
items.summary: A WARNING THAT THIS STORY CONTAINS GRAPHIC ELEMENTS THAT MAY DISTRESS SOME PEOPLE. There are fears for tens of thousands of civilians trapped in the western Sudanese city of Al Fasher, after the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces overran the military's last stronghold in the Darfur region. Aid groups and observers are now documenting cases of mass killings and other atrocities. SBS spoke with Nathaniel Raymond of the Yale Humanitarian Research Lab about the gravity of the crisis.

items.title: Mass evacuations in Cuba as Hurricane Melissa leaves Jamaica a disaster zone
items.summary: Hurricane Melissa is regathering strength as it makes way towards Cuba, where mass evacuations are taking place. Jamaica has officially been declared a disaster zone after Melissa swept through as a Category Five storm, weakening to a Category Four. The Caribbean disaster has left at least seven people dead with casualties reported in Jamaica, Haiti and the Dominican Republic.

items.title: Government housing affordability scheme under pressure
items.summary: The Housing Australia Future Fund (HAFF) is under intense political scrutiny following the launch of a forensic nine-month federal audit. The $10 billion scheme, intended to boost social and affordable housing, is accused by the Opposition of wasting taxpayer funds and overpaying for properties. The debate has been dominated by the fund's slow delivery and expert concerns that its structure incentivises market-tied "fake affordable" rents over genuine public housing.

items.title: No more interest rate cuts: Inflation sparks bank warning
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Belinda Allen from the Commonwealth Bank who is now predicting an end to the Reserve Bank cutting cycle, following a stronger than expected rise in September quarter inflation, while Sally Auld from NAB says there's still a chance of a cut in May; plus a look at the market reaction with Jun Bei Liu fom TenCap.

items.title: 'Had to tie myself to the bed': Aussie details Hurricane Melissa terror in Jamaica
items.summary: Hurricane Melissa — one of the most powerful hurricanes on record — has ripped a path of destruction through Jamaica.

items.title: 'Sadistic': AFP flags new threat as Australian links to 'paedophile' network investigated
items.summary: AFP commissioner Krissy Barrett described a "new, twisted type of gamification" in online networks targeting young girls.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 29 October 2025
items.summary: A five minute bulletin for English language learners

items.title: ‘Time for truth’: Western Australia Governor apologises for Pinjarra Massacre, nearly 200 years on
items.summary: The Western Australian Governor has apologised for his predecessor's role in a state-led violent attack against Noongar men, women and children almost 200 years ago, known as the Pinjarra massacre. Descendants of the Bindjareb Noongar people received the long-awaited apology saying it is a meaningful step towards reconciliation.

items.title: 'Rwanda-level': Fears of mass killings as thousands trapped in Sudan's Al-Fasher
items.summary: The capture of Al-Fasher, the historic heart of Darfur, has sparked fears of mass killings reminiscent of the region's darkest days.

items.title: Housing and migration the big issues as Dutch voters cast their ballots
items.summary: Voters in the Netherlands have begun casting their ballots in the country’s general election. Polls suggest the hard-right anti-immigration party led by Geert Wilders is likely to win the most seats, however that doesn’t mean he’ll lead a new government. The campaign has been dominated by housing and immigration with concern about asylum seekers being scapegoated.

items.title: Hurricane Melissa: 'Storm of the century' takes aim at Cuba after roaring across Jamaica
items.summary: At its peak, the storm packed ferocious sustained winds of 300km/h.

items.title: Israel launches deadly strikes on Gaza, but US says ceasefire is holding
items.summary: US vice president JD Vance said that despite the latest flare-up, "the ceasefire is holding".

items.title: The diseases that dominate Australia's $270 billion health bill
items.summary: Australia's disease and injury spending has grown by more than $10 billion. Here's what we spent it on.

items.title: Perimenopause nearly killed me. Angry, I have a message for women
items.summary: Perimenopause left Shelly Horton broken mentally and physically. Now, she's determined to change the dialogue around this stage of life.

items.title: CSL and Wisetech shares smashed & Australia's ASEAN opportunities
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Australia's Special Envoy to Southeast Asia Nicholas Moore to find out how regional leaders feel about doing business with Australians as he attends the ASEAN summit; plus Michael Jenneke from UBS Management takes a look at the day's sharemarket action as CSL and Wisetech shares crash.

items.title: Kidney disease drug added to PBS, helping 65,000 Australians
items.summary: The federal government will add a medicine for chronic kidney disease into the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. More than 65.000 Australians are expected to benefit from the cheaper access to Jardiance , also known as Empagliflozin.

items.title: States face fresh scrutiny in youth justice shake-up after 'deeply disturbing' evidence
items.summary: Inquiry to examine if children's rights are violated in custody and if Australia is upholding its international obligations.

items.title: 'I did it': Accused assassin admits murdering former Japanese PM Shinzo Abe
items.summary: Tetsuya Yamagami, 45, was arrested at the scene of the shooting in July 2022 after allegedly firing at Shinzo Abe with a homemade gun.

items.title: A prisoner, an exile or a politician: Who do Palestinians want as their future president?
items.summary: Three contenders to lead a future Palestinian state have emerged, but experts say only one is a viable option for Gaza and the West Bank.

items.title: Environmental law overhaul sparks political storm in Canberra
items.summary: The long-awaited overhaul of Australia’s national environmental law is set to ignite Parliament this week, as the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act (EPBC) faces its first major reform in twenty-six years. This second attempt at a package, featuring an independent EPA and a new National Interest power, has already generated a political firestorm. The Opposition is demanding the bill be split, while the Greens warn the entire package is "riddled with loopholes."

items.title: The 'quick and easy' way Australians could boost their super by $2,590
items.summary: Billions of dollars in superannuation is waiting to be claimed — and it's not the only lost and unclaimed money that's out there.

items.title: Queensland reinstates puberty blocker ban hours after state's top court overturns it
items.summary: Despite a court ruling overturning the ban, Queensland’s health minister has issued a new directive blocking puberty blockers for transgender youth.

items.title: Burke confirms first cohort of NZYQ deportees in Nauru
items.summary: The first cohort of NZYQ deportees has arrived in Nauru, under a removal pathway expected to cost taxpayers $2.5 billion.

items.title: Nationals senator says TikTok bullied his office amid new teen social media ban details

items.summary: These Australians say a visit from Prime Minister Anthony Albanese would send a "strong signal" to regional communities.

items.title: Outback town in 'complete and utter shock' after two killed in underground mine explosion
items.summary: The dead have not yet been formally identified, but they are believed to be a woman in her 20s and a man in his 60s, who had both been living in Cobar.

items.title: Trump leaves door open for unconstitutional third term: 'I would love to do it'
items.summary: Steve Bannon, the pro-Trump podcaster and former White House chief strategist, has said there was a plan to circumvent the US 22nd amendment.

items.summary: Students have long led anti-war movements in Australia. The first national vote in 50 years has taken on the question of weapons company links.

items.title: Osamah is the first to arrive in Australia via this new visa pathway. His long 'limbo' is over
items.summary: The 24-year-old, originally from Yemen, is one of just 20 refugees due to come to Australia as part of this pilot program.

items.title: US China optimism boosts ASX ahead of global rate decisions
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Elio D'Amato from EnviroInvest about why investors are increasingly optimistic of a US China trade deal ahead of leadership talks, as some global central banks prepare to cut interest rates this week.

items.summary: The elections were the first test for Milei since he won office in 2023 on a promise to revive the economy through a series of reforms.

items.summary: Labor's overhaul of environmental protections is already at risk, with the Coalition demanding parts of the bill be delayed.

items.summary: Israel says an Iranian commander was also the mastermind behind attacks in Greece and Germany.

items.title: Japan calls on Australia to strengthen ties as Quad alliance strains under Trump

items.title: I'm a member of the 'sandwich generation'. I scoff at the term
items.summary: Phyllis Foundis cares for her elderly mother and two teenage sons. To truly show up for them, she's had to learn how to care for herself too.

items.title: 'Shadow fleet' still appearing in Australian supply chains despite sanctions, research finds
items.summary: US and EU sanctions on Russia's largest oil companies this week has left refineries in China and India assessing their implications. Some sell refined products to Australia. But will the latest measures be able to capture Russia's shadow fleet that exploit sanction loopholes? Exclusive data shared with SBS has shown vessels transporting Russian crude oil and previously sanctioned by the Federal government still appear in the supply chains of Australian companies.

items.title: Who gets to be called Aussie? Why these posters are causing another stir — 10 years on
items.summary: Artist Peter Drew is reinvigorating his conversation-starting artworks about what it really means to be Australian.

items.summary: The players have been offered support, and are believed to be ready to continue playing in the tournament.

items.title: Labor moves to create Australia's first national environment watchdog
items.summary: The proposed environment protection agency is part of a raft of reforms to federal environmental laws.

items.title: How a literacy and numeracy program is helping adults open up career options
items.summary: One in five Australians, or around three-million adults, have low literacy or numeracy skills - and it can have a big impact on how people are able to engage in every day life. Programs are in place across the country to help people improve their skills and achieve their life goals. Including one in Tasmania, helping adults become work ready.

items.title: Are aliens from space waiting to invade? Probably not, say the scientists
items.summary: The prospect for an alien invasion of Earth has been flooding the Internet in recent weeks thanks to the object 3-I-ATLAS currently hurtling through our solar system which some have warned may be an alien spacecraft that can attack our planet. Spoiler alert - NASA says it isn't. But even so, the fears of alien invasion are nothing new: in the final years of the nineteenth century, in his novel War of the Worlds, British author H G Wells wrote that 'minds immeasurably greater than our own, across the gulf of space, made their plans against us'. So what is the likelihood of an alien invasion? In this edition of Weekend One on One, Jason Wright, professor of astronomy and astrophysics at Penn State University and director of the Penn State Extraterrestrial Intelligence Centre looks into whether it could happen here.

items.title: The 'horrendous' gamble of fast-tracking the Trump-Albanese critical minerals deal
items.summary: The $13 billion deal has been widely celebrated, but some warn "stark changes" pose a risk to the environment and food.

items.title: INTERVIEW: 'Deaths of Despair': the deadly dangers of homelessness
items.summary: New data shows Australians experiencing homelessness are more likely to die from overdose, suicide or coronary heart disease, with potentially nine avoidable deaths every day. Data from the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare has found that around 43,200 people with a history of homelessness died between 2012 and 2013 alone from these types of causes. The median age was 55 years, far lower than the Australian median life expectancy of 81.1 years for men and 85.1 years for women. For women, gendered violence remains a leading cause of homelessness across Australia, impacting almost 67,000 people every year. Kate Colvin is the CEO of Homelessness Australia and she's been talking to SBS's Cameron Carr.

items.title: Anthony Albanese and Donald Trump are on their way to Asia. Here's what's on their agendas
items.summary: The prime minister and US president will visit Malaysia and South Korea for regional summits.

items.title: Pannir couldn't speak to the media from death row. He wrote poetry instead
items.summary: Singapore has executed 14 prisoners this year. Among them was Pannir, hanged earlier this month for a first-time drug offence.

items.title: Revealed: Sanctioned Russian 'shadow' tankers in Australian oil product supply chains
items.summary: Data shows more than a third of oil tankers from Russia's 'shadow fleet' sanctioned in June are supplying Australian companies.

items.title: Peanut butter loving babies are licking allergies, study suggests
items.summary: A decade after a landmark study proved that feeding peanut products to young babies could prevent them developing life-threatening allergies, a new US study has shown it's making a big difference in the real world. The study has found about 60,000 children in the United States have avoided developing peanut allergies after new guidance was issued in 2015 about when to introduce the allergen to youngsters.

items.title: Traditional owners mark 40th anniversary of Uluru handback in London
items.summary: Anangu traditional owners have marked 40 years since Uluru Kata Tjuta National Park was handed back to their people. The handback was a landmark moment for Aboriginal land rights in Australia and a powerful recognition of the enduring connection between First Nations peoples and Country. The official celebrations have included a trip to London for a delegation of nine Anangu traditional owners, who met with High Commissioner to the UK Stephen Smith, and King Charles, as part of the official commemorations.

items.title: Why some Australians stand by the royal family despite the Prince Andrew scandal
items.summary: Polls show Australians have little sympathy for Prince Andrew — yet backing for the royal family and constitutional monarchy remains steady. Why?

items.title: The 'vicious cycle' that could see the most prescribed drugs in Australia become obsolete
items.summary: Common infections are becoming more resistant to treatment, and it's leaving experts worried for vulnerable groups.

items.title: Spotlight on US, Australia inflation; super balances hit new record
items.summary: The ASX-200 has ended the week in the red, as investors await the outcome of Donald Trump’s much-anticipated meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping at the APEC Summit next week. Attention is also turning to the release of key September CPI data in the US, despite the government shutdown.

items.title: How does your balance compare? Australians reach a $172k super milestone
items.summary: There has also been a "historic" retirement shift, according to a peak body. Here's how much Australians have in their accounts.

items.title: West Bank faces threat of annexation as Knesset vote condemned by US officials
items.summary: More aid is entering Gaza under a fragile ceasefire, but humanitarian agencies say it remains far from enough to meet the needs of its starving population. But discussions on how to achieve – and maintain – peace have coincided with Israel's Knesset narrowly advancing a bill to apply Israeli law to the occupied West Bank. It's being widely condemned as a preliminary step to approving total annexation.

items.title: New US, EU sanctions aim to pressure Russia towards ceasefire
items.summary: The United States has unveiled its most forceful move yet to pressure Russia into ending the war in Ukraine. President Donald Trump has announced broad sanctions on Russia’s two biggest oil giants, Rosneft and Lukoil. The measures mark a decisive shift in tone from the US, targeting the lifeblood of Russia’s economy in a bid to choke off Russia's Ukraine war funding

items.title: Optus executives step down as triple-zero disaster fallout continues
items.summary: The announcement didn’t suggest the departures were related to a recent Optus triple-zero outage, which has been linked to three deaths.

items.title: Albo, Trump and the elephant in the room, Gaza ceasefire fractures & a very French heist
items.summary: In this episode: Behind the scenes of Prime Minister Anthony Albanese’s highly anticipated meeting with US President Donald Trump, while Ukraine’s leader Vlodymyr Zelenskyy walks away from the White House without his Tomahawk missiles. Plus, more threats to the Gaza ceasefire despite optimism from US Vice President JD Vance, the ‘high-stakes’ meeting between the Australian and Indonesian military chiefs, and how a daring daylight robbery unfolded at the Louvre.

items.title: Israel ordered to allow aid into Gaza, ICJ rules
items.summary: The International Court of Justice has issued an advisory opinion, stating that as the occupying power, Israel has failed to provide adequate humanitarian supplies to Gaza’s civilian population. The Israeli parliament has just narrowly approved a preliminary bill to apply Israeli civil law to the occupied West Bank, a move viewed internationally as a step towards annexation.

items.title: Australia to send ADF liaison officer to join US-led Gaza peace taskforce
items.summary: The US has agreed to provide up to 200 troops to support the Gaza taskforce and stabilise the ceasefire between Israel and Hamas.

items.title: Top UN court says Israel must allow aid into Gaza to meet 'basic needs' of Palestinians
items.summary: The wide-ranging ICJ ruling, quickly rejected by Israel, came as aid groups scrambled to scale up humanitarian assistance into Gaza.

items.title: Chris was using a sunscreen while he recovered from throat cancer. Then it was recalled
items.summary: More than 20 sunscreen products have been taken off Australian shelves. For the most vulnerable, it's prompted "sunscreen anxiety".

items.title: Boom towns: Australia's surging suburbs, record prices and Brisbane's rise to No. 2
items.summary: It's been a strong quarter for the housing market, according to a new report. Find out which suburbs saw the biggest gains.

items.title: Japan's Sanae Takaichi makes history but will it change things for Japanese women?
items.summary: Sanae Takaichi took office on Tuesday as Japan's first female prime minister but on the same day she appointed only two female ministers in a 19-member cabinet.

items.summary: After more than a year of rapid growth, gold experienced its biggest single-day fall in over a decade overnight.

items.title: Investor warning about FOMO as gold stocks tumble
items.summary: The gold price has seen its worst one day fall in 12 years as gold stocks tumble after their recent run. Similarly, rare earths also slide. SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Cameron Gleeson from Betashares and Scott Phillips from The Motley Fool to find out why some investors are pressing the sell button and offers a reality check.

items.title: Gaza ceasefire going 'better than expected', JD Vance says on Israel trip
items.summary: More than a week into the Gaza ceasefire, senior US officials have visited Israel to discuss ways to progress to the next stage of Donald Trump's 20-point peace plan. Flareups of violence in recent days has threatened to unravel the ceasefire. Meanwhile, the United Nations says it is important the ceasefire holds - to allow for aid deliveries to be scaled up in Gaza.

items.title: Battlefields, boardrooms, briefing rooms: Ukraine war drags on after delays in ceasefire talks
items.summary: Diplomacy has overtaken the battlefield in the Ukraine war, with Washington, Moscow, and Kyiv offering starkly different paths to peace. The Kremlin says no Trump-Putin summit date is set, while Washington insists leverage not concessions will end the war.

items.title: Breastfeeding reduces the risk of breast cancer, researchers say
items.summary: Australian researchers have found breastfeeding can protect women against breast cancer by building up their immunity. According to a new study, pregnancy and breastfeeding produces infection-fighting T-cells that help guard against abnormal cells that could develop into cancer.

items.title: Windy city: Victorians left without power and NSW heat records smashed in 'extreme' day
items.summary: A heat "bubble" from the outback smashed temperature records across NSW, while damaging and destructive winds left 14,000 Victorians without power.
